markdown: How your appestat* and sugar can control weight. Your "appestat" is a kind of hunger switch in your brain. When it's turned up, you're hungry. And you may overeat. Sugar turns your appestat down—helps you eat less. Read how. <::A close-up, black and white image shows a person's hand adjusting the weights on a mechanical balance scale. The hand, wearing a ring on the ring finger, is positioned in the center of the frame, with fingers gripping the sliding weight on the upper beam of the scale. The scale's beam is marked with numbers, with visible markings including '0', '3', '4', '14', '16', '18', '20', '22', '24', '26', '28', '30', '32', '34', '36'. Another larger sliding weight is partially visible on a lower beam, showing the number '50'. The background is plain and light, highlighting the scale and hand.: figure::> In these days of artificial sweeteners and fad diets, you may have some trouble thinking of ordinary sugar as a key to weight control. But that's exactly what sugar can be to you when you understand how your appestat and sugar work together. When your _blood sugar level_ is low, your appestat is turned way up, and you're hungry. You're apt to eat more than you need, before your blood sugar level can rise again. So what you do is this: when you're very hungry, take a little sugar—in coffee, a soft drink, ice cream, pastry, or candy. Sugar raises your blood sugar level faster than any other food. (Artificial sweeteners have no effect on blood sugar level.) And then your hunger switches off. As a result, you can eat less and feel better when you keep sugar in your diet. The calories in sugar burn up fast and they give you energy to go on. And sugar tastes good, too. Do you need any more reasons to stay with sugar? Only 18 calories per teaspoon— and it's all energy. <::A white sugar bowl with a spoon inside, filled with sugar. The lid of the sugar bowl is placed next to it. Both the bowl and the lid have a decorative pattern of small leaf-like shapes.::> *"A neural center in the hypothalamus believed to regulate appetite." - Webster's Third New International Dictionary. SUGAR INFORMATION, INC. P.O. Box 2664, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10017 This advertisement appears in *Life*, February 23, 1968, *Good Housekeeping*, March 1968, and *Redbook*, March 1968. Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/qqyv0228 (Printed in U.S.A.)

chunks.markdown: How your appestat* and sugar can control weight.
Your "appestat" is a kind of hunger switch in your brain. When it's turned up, you're hungry. And you may overeat.
Sugar turns your appestat down—helps you eat less. Read how.

<::A close-up, black and white image shows a person's hand adjusting the weights on a mechanical balance scale. The hand, wearing a ring on the ring finger, is positioned in the center of the frame, with fingers gripping the sliding weight on the upper beam of the scale. The scale's beam is marked with numbers, with visible markings including '0', '3', '4', '14', '16', '18', '20', '22', '24', '26', '28', '30', '32', '34', '36'. Another larger sliding weight is partially visible on a lower beam, showing the number '50'. The background is plain and light, highlighting the scale and hand.: figure::>

In these days of artificial sweeteners and fad diets, you may have some trouble thinking of ordinary sugar as a key to weight control. But that's exactly what sugar can be to you when you understand how your appestat and sugar work together.

When your _blood sugar level_ is low, your appestat is turned way up, and you're hungry. You're apt to eat more than you need, before your blood sugar level can rise again. So what you do is this: when you're very hungry, take

a little sugar—in coffee, a soft drink, ice cream, pastry, or candy. Sugar raises your blood sugar level faster than any other food. (Artificial sweeteners have no effect on blood sugar level.) And then your hunger switches off. As a result, you can eat less and feel better when you keep sugar in your diet.
The calories in sugar burn up fast and they give you energy to go on. And sugar tastes good, too. Do you need any more reasons to stay with sugar?

Only 18 calories per teaspoon— and it's all energy. <::A white sugar bowl with a spoon inside, filled with sugar. The lid of the sugar bowl is placed next to it. Both the bowl and the lid have a decorative pattern of small leaf-like shapes.::>
*"A neural center in the hypothalamus believed to regulate appetite." - Webster's Third New International Dictionary.
SUGAR INFORMATION, INC. P.O. Box 2664, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10017
This advertisement appears in *Life*, February 23, 1968, *Good Housekeeping*, March 1968, and *Redbook*, March 1968.
